revision.text: {|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name=H5Y |image=H5Y-2.jpg |caption=Yokosuka H5Y Type 99 Flying Boat "Cherry" }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type=[[Flying boat]] |manufacturer=[[Yokosuka Naval Air Technical Arsenal|Yokosuka]] |designer= |first flight=[[1936 in aviation|1936]] |introduced=[[1939 in aviation|1939]] |retired= |status= |primary user=[[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service]] (IJNAS) |more users= |produced=1938 - 1941 |number built=20 |unit cost= |variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Yokosuka H5Y''' (short designation) or '''Yokosuka Navy Type 99 Flying Boat Model 11''' (九九式飛行艇, ''99shiki hikōtei'') (long designation), given the allied code name '''Cherry''', was an IJNAS [[flying boat]] in service from 1938. ==Design and development== The H5Y was designed by Yokosuka to meet an IJNAS requirement for a twin-engine [[Maritime patrol aircraft|maritime reconnaissance]] flying boat, which was intended to match the performance of contemporary four-engine flying boats, while being cheaper to build and easier to maintain. Two prototypes were built at the [[Hiro Naval Arsenal|11th Naval Arsenal, Hiro]], being completed in 1936.{{Harvnb|Green|1972|pp=136–137.}} The H5Y was a twin-engine [[parasol wing]] aircraft, and thus resembled a scaled-down version of the [[Kawanishi H6K]] "Mavis". Performance was found to be poor however, with the aircraft underpowered and suffering from structural problems which delayed production. Only 20 were built between 1936 and 1941. Yokosuka Naval Air Arsenal built the aircraft at the [[Dai-Juichi Kaigun Kokusho]] facility.{{Harvnb|Mikesh and Abe|1990|p=262.}}{{Harvnb|Francillon|1979|p=495.}} ==Operational history== The H5Y was accepted for production in 1938 as the '''Type 99 Flying Boat Model 11''', production deliveries starting in 1939. However, production was quickly cancelled owing to the poor performance, only 20 being built.{{harvnb|Donald|1997|p=?.}} Although some were used for coastal [[Anti-submarine warfare|anti-submarine]] patrols early in [[World War II]], they were quickly transferred to second line duties such as [[Military transport aircraft|transport]] or [[Flight training|training]]. ==Variants== ;H5Y :2 Prototypes constructed at the [[Hiro Naval Arsenal]] ;H5Y1 :Production model, 18 built. ;Yokosuka Navy Type 99 Flying Boat Model 11 :The long formal designation of the H5Y. ==Operators== ;{{JPN}} * [[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service]] ==Specifications (Yokosuka H5Y1)== {{aircraft specifications| |plane or copter?= plane |jet or prop?= prop |ref=''Warplanes of the Second World War, Volume Five: Flying Boats'' |crew= 6 |length main= 20.53 m |length alt= 67 ft 4 in |span main= 31.57 m |span alt= 103 ft 7½in |height main= 6.71 m |height alt= 22 ft 0 in |area main= 107.7 m² |area alt= 1,159 ft² |empty weight main= 7,070 kg |empty weight alt= 15,554 lb |max takeoff weight main= 11,500 kg |max takeoff weight alt= 25,353 lb |engine (prop)= [[Mitsubishi Shinten|Mitsubishi MK1A Shinten]]-21 |type of prop= 14-cylinder air-cooled radials |number of props= 2 |power main= 895 kW |power alt= 1,200 hp |max speed main= 303 km/h |max speed alt= 163 kn, 188 mph |range main= 4,800 km |range alt= 2,591 nmi, 2,980 mi |ceiling main= 5,200 m |ceiling alt= 17,000 ft |climb rate main= |climb rate alt= |loading main= |loading alt= |power/mass main= |power/mass alt= |more performance= *'''Endurance:''' 26 hr *'''Climb to 3,000 m (9,850 ft):''' 24 min |guns= 3× 7.7 mm (.303 in) [[machine gun]]s |bombs= 2× 250 kg (552 lb) bombs }} ==See also== {{aircontent| |related aircraft= |similar aircraft= |lists= * [[List of aircraft of World War II]] *[[List of flying boats]] *[[List of military aircraft of Japan]] }} ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|2}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} * Donald, David (Editor). ''The Encyclopedia of World Aircraft''. Aerospace Publishing, 1997. ISBN 1-85605-375-X. * Francillon, Ph.D., René J. ''Japanese Aircraft of the Pacific War''. London: Putnam & Company Ltd., 1970 (2nd edition 1979). ISBN 0-370-30251-6. * Green, William. ''Warplanes of the Second World War, Volume Five: Flying Boats''. London: Macdonald & Co.(Publishers) Ltd., 1962 (5th impression 1972). ISBN 0-356-01449-5. {{refend}} ==External links== {{commons category|Yokosuka H5Y}} * [http://www.combinedfleet.com/ijna/h5y.htm www.combinedfleet.com] * [http://www.fsdome.com/aviation-encyclopedia/planes/country/japan/planes/96.htm www.fsdome.com] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050424171306/http://www.csd.uwo.ca/~pettypi/elevon/gustin_military/db/jap/H5YYOKOS.html] {{Yokosuka aircraft}} {{Japanese Navy Flying Boats}} {{Allied reporting names}} [[Category:Yokosuka aircraft|H5Y]] [[Category:Japanese military reconnaissance aircraft 1930–1939|H5Y, Yokosuka]] [[Category:Flying boats]] [[Category:Twin-engined tractor aircraft]] [[Category:Parasol-wing aircraft]]
